text: We'll hear argument now in Number 87-1245, Texas Monthly versus Bob Bullock.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court:
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
What about the message of the Arkansas case?
The Arkansas case, Your Honor, the way Texas views the Arkansas case is that in that particular case, you had a different tax structure than what you have in Texas.
Well, but it was a free... a freedom of the press case?
It did involve the issue of First Amendment right, free press, yes, Your Honor.
And here some publications are, some parts of the press are taxed and some aren't, in this case.
Texas taxes all parts of the press except for religious periodicals.
So, some are taxed and some aren't--
The state does not--
--based on content.

--The way the state reads Arkansas Writers' Project is that to have a First Amendment violation, there must be a tax that singles out the press as a whole and targets the press for that tax, or it must target a small group within the press.
I'm not sure that I understand that.
--Yes.
And, therefore, the public harmed by the exemption is not just the rest of the press, but rather the entire body politic.
Yes, Your Honor.
Texas Monthly would not get its money back under that, is that right?

Not at that point in time, Your Honor, until a decision was made as to whether religious periodicals become subject to the tax because under the current tax structure, all sales of tangible personal property are taxable.
Ms. Burke, what if I think it's unconstitutional for the Texas courts to say after the fact, after the years have passed, we are retroactively going to subject religious periodicals to taxes?
It's an unusual procedure, Your Honor.
Well, that doesn't harm anybody, though, to do that.
Of course, Your Honor, there would be a limitations time period running against the state on necessities taxes.
Is this Appellant the only entity that has filed a protest on this theory?
No, Your Honor.
And has the statute run as to all others, because, I take it, this statute has been repealed, the one that we're looking at?
The statute was repealed in 1987, effective October 1, 1987.
Has the time run on any further protests?
No, Your Honor.
Four-year, a four-year statute?
Yes, sir.
So, if we told this appellant that it could get its money back, then any number of others could file?
That is correct, Your Honor.
Ms. Burke, let me interrupt you just a moment.
--No, Your Honor, there is nothing in the record and I do not have that kind of evidence since the state has not been taxing religious organizations.
Do you have any figures in the record or that you know of what the gross revenue from the state sales tax is in any given year?
Your Honor, it is the largest revenue-raising tax in the state of Texas.
Ms. Burke, may I ask you on the status point, the first prong, what about an organization of atheists who published a magazine promulgating their views about religion?
I believe it might, Your Honor.
The statute said religious faith.
Yes, it is, Your Honor, but it is a belief, even though it's anti-religion.
You would interpret religious faith to include anti-religious faith?
Yes, in a sense.
That's stretching it about as far as you can, isn't it?
Yes, but the state has tried to accommodate religion to the extent that it can, and I believe I'm correct on that.
How in the world does that accommodate religion?
How do you... accommodation is by allowing the organization to be free from having to support the state.
Wouldn't you have to name religion and atheism?
No, unless--
And that was deliberate.
--the state considers atheism to be a form of faith.
And the distinction was deliberately made by the state.
The state legislature did make a deliberate enactment to exempt religious-type periodicals being distributed by a religious faith.
Ms. Burke, you don't take the position that this accommodation is required, do you, by the free exercise clause?
Your Honor, as I understand the free exercise clause, it does mandate that accommodation be required.
So, you take the position that Texas may not impose a general sales tax on religious publications?
No, Your Honor.
Well, that's what I'm asking.
--to impose the tax.
Can the state impose its sales tax on the sale of candles in a Catholic church, too?
Yes, Your Honor, it could.
Two points.
